meanings.def: an attractive quality of movement that is smooth and done with control; a simple and beautiful quality
examples: She moves with the natural grace of a ballerina.
a debut album of uncommon grace and beauty

meanings.def: a quality of behaviour that is polite and pleasant and deserves respect
examples: He conducted himself with grace and dignity throughout the trial.

meanings.def: ways of behaving that people think are polite and acceptable
examples: He was not particularly well versed in the social graces.

meanings.def: extra time that is given to somebody to enable them to pay a bill, finish a piece of work, etc.
examples: They've given me a month's grace to get the money.

meanings.def: the love that God shows towards the human race
examples: the power of divine grace
It was only by the grace of God that they survived.
The mantra bestows Siva's grace upon the devotee.

meanings.def: a short prayer that is usually said before a meal to thank God for the food
examples: Let's say grace.

meanings.def: used as a title of respect when talking to or about an archbishop, a duke or a duchess
examples: Good Morning, Your Grace.
Their Graces the Duke and Duchess of Kent.

meanings.def: a way of behaving that shows that somebody thinks that they are more important, etc. than they really are
examples: Even when he became a star he didn’t have any airs and graces.

meanings.def: to have somebody’s approval and be liked by them
to lose the trust or respect that people have for you, especially by doing something bad or morally wrong
a situation in which somebody loses the trust or respect that people have for them, especially because they have done something that is bad or morally wrong
examples: The biography explains the circumstances surrounding her fall from grace.

meanings.def: to be polite enough to do something, especially when you have done something wrong
examples: He didn't even have the grace to look embarrassed.

meanings.def: (in the Roman Catholic Church) having been forgiven by God for the wrong or evil things you have done
examples: He died in a state of grace.

meanings.def: used to say that you could easily have been in the same difficult or unpleasant situation that somebody else is in
in an unwilling and/or rude way
examples: He handed over the money with typical bad grace.

meanings.def: in a willing and pleasant way
examples: You must learn to accept defeat with good grace.
We will simply have to accept the situation with a good grace.

meanings.def: any particular year after the birth of Christ

meanings.def: to make something more attractive; to decorate something
examples: The table had once graced a duke's drawing room.
We sat at a small table graced with a vase of fresh flowers.

meanings.def: to bring honour to somebody/something; to be kind enough to attend or take part in something
examples: grace somebody/something She is one of the finest players ever to have graced the game.
The occasion was graced by the presence of Lord and Lady Thomson.
grace somebody/something with something (ironic) Will you be gracing us with your presence tonight?

meanings.def: a first name for girls

(1928-82) a US film star from a rich Irish-American family in Philadelphia who became Princess Grace of Monaco when she married in 1956. She received an Oscar for The Country Girl (1954), and her other films included High Noon, Rear Window (1954) and High Society (1956).
